comments.commentBody: Eddie-That smoking is harmful has always been obvious. But what diseases does it cause? How can we minimize and reverse those diseases? How can we diagnose those diseases and who should be screened?  These are important questions that deserve attention.  It is not a wasted effort.

WHO reports 5 million annual global lung disease deaths caused by automotive and industrial air pollution. MIT reports that 200,000 of those deaths are in the US. Those people also die gasping with an oxygen tank. I'm not defending smoking. But why is tobacco demonized while the other killers are always let off scot free?  Maybe it's because those who belch out deadly particulate matter from their SUVs don't wish to admit their culpability in killing their fellow citizens?
My last smoke, a Camel straight, was crushed out at 11:57 on Nov. 16, 1987. On Jan 3, 2015, I was diagnosed with COPD in an ER at the age of 62.

Hi Loomy. I was you 8 1/2 years ago. I did quit though, and that means that you can too. I used the filters called "One Step At A Time". I also visited a website called ,  why quit.com. It has a lot of useful information that helped support me during the tough times. I would go back and read things again and again. It's an addiction. It's not your friend. Maybe it's time for you too to quit.

I smoke a pipe. I love everything about it - the taste, the aromas, the ritual, the relaxation, and collecting beautiful pipes as art objects. As with cigars, one doesn't inhale when smoking a pipe.

But doctors don't know what to make of a moderate pipe habit... probably because there's no box to check for "pipe smoker" in the patient records software they use.
Nic patches have terrible side effects? Since when? I used them (successfully) to quit smoking, and the only side effect I noticed was acid-trip dreams.

I quit smoking as a young adult, but would still love to have a cigarette and a cup of coffee.  It is really hard to quit.  My dearest love is killing herself with Marlboros.  She's tried so many times to quit.   I have read articles that compare nicotine addiction to heroin addiction, and I believe it. But the help that is given to smokers is practically nothing - nicotine patches, a drug with terrible side effects, or mostly urgings by doctors to quit, using will power.  Will power worked for me, but I think that in-patient rehab should be available to smokers, just as it is to drug addicts.  Why don't insurance carriers provide serious help for the deeply addicted?  Believe me, it would have been cheaper financially than the health care they must provide now to my dearest.  Watching someone you love slowly decline, unable to breathe - it's terrible.

"mandatory and verifiable nicotine rehabilitation" What is that?  If they made inpatient rehab available for nicotine addicts as they do for heroin addicts, that would be great for the deeply addicted.  But although you and I can quit with will power, there are many, many who can not. All the nicotine patches and Chantrix in the world will not work for that level of addiction.  I hate the tobacco companies, and I am enraged that the States settled those tobacco law suits and did NOT develop any plan for helping addicts quit.  Here in Pennsylvania, there is a state-funded support telephone number, period, end of help.  That is nothing, nothing, nothing for someone who is deeply addicted to nicotine, although it does terrible damage just as heroin does.
It is an addiction, but it is not recognized or treated as one.  People "urge" smokers to stop, and then that's that.  You could get more help (and more sympathy) as a heroin addict than as a smoker.
Good luck mate, or matey as you wish!  CHEERS.

How fortunate for you, Doone. Most people die of something by the time they're 88.

My father died of lung cancer at 70, but he'd stopped smoking about eight years earlier. My mother stopped perhaps 18 years before she died of lung cancer at 75.

My first cousin died of lung cancer at 58. He, too, had smoked and quit.

When I see people puffing at cigarettes, I think I am seeing the word "stupid" coming out in smoke rings above their heads. When they live beyond 80 or so years, they're lucky.

Dave, not all diabetics are obese.

And I think that gun owners should, yes, pay dearly for every gun they purchase beyond their first one and taxed yearly. A good idea!

"Doctors, who are often reluctant to urge patients with symptoms to quit smoking..." This has not been my experience as an NP. Every doctor, NP and PA I know strongly urges people to quit smoking, whether they have symptoms or not. All of us have seen the devastating effects of long-term smoking, and we are eager to help our patients quit and avoid, or at least minimize, those effects. Like my colleagues, I bring smoking up at every visit, and especially when the patient has a respiratory illness or other symptoms. The message does get through to some patients, but repetition -- done in a kind, concerned way -- can work.

My mother quit cold-turkey when a vein broke in her nose -- probably thinned by smoking, the surgeon told her -- and she spent two weeks in hospital with about ten feet of gauze packed in her head. She almost died.

My father, not wanting to smoke around her when she came back home, smoked for about three days on the front porch and then also gave it up, just like that.

Too late -- the damage was already done.

But it's good to throw the cigarettes away. Who knows? Perhaps you'll live longer than my parents did.

I do, RingO.

And children of smokers also get more ear and sinus infections, alas.

And he lived a long life, longer than many live who don't smoke. My opinion--something will get me in the end so I may as well enjoy my parliaments every now and then (I do boot camp and Intervall training 3 times a week) and take my chances
I smoke a few cigarettes a week. I know it's stupid but they taste good (American Spirit) & relieve stress. I've tried to quit but then there will be some mini-crisis & I'll reach for one.
I know smoking is bad, I am a smoker myself. But I appreciate your sentiment no one gets out of here alive.

Lots of things that are bad for people are legal. As far as I'm concerned, most fast food is just as bad. Should we outlaw that, too? It's a slippery slope once the government gets into the prohibition business, as history has shown.

Tax cigarettes so that the:
tax/pack times the # of packs sold /year, = the health expenditures from smoking related diseases. Monies to be used only to defray health related costs.
That way, smokers will self-insure.

kudos for being honest. I was like you until I had a a few months of stress at work and ended up smoking a pack a day. it took me a week of not surrounding myself with triggers followed by nicotine patches to let go. once I quit for 2 weeks - I emerged into a new found clarity of sensing the world.

I will admit I smoke, I have quit many times often for years. Do I kick myself for going back to smoking, sure do. But I will quit again, I am very disciplined when I put my mind to it. No worries there. But I do want to say, that in comparison to my non smoking friends and family, I rarely ever get a cold, respiratory infections, sinus infections or have allergies. I don't think I have been prescribed antibiotics more than 5-6 times in my life. I have a healthy complexion, no wrinkles (I do stay out of the sun, wear sunscreen). Good genes, probably, thank God. But I will quit smoking soon, why -- I don't like being held hostage to what is arguably a smelly, unpleasant, socially repugnant and expensive habit.

My boyfriend smoked for decades, oblivious to the dangers - and since he appeared to be in the best of health, nothing could dissuade him; in any event he believed in living for the moment; all
I could do was open windows whenever he smoked.

Two years ago he was diagnosed not with lung cancer, the disease I feared, but with cancer of the tongue. Radical surgeries spared his life, but he aged 10 years overnight and can no longer chew food - no more going out to eat, or travel as he loved to. In remission, life is now infinitely precious.

He says he never expected this to happen; but alas, had someone warned him, I think he would have nevertheless continued with his habit, since it is hardly news that smoking is bad for your health.

YES YOU CAN.

I was a total addict. Hardest thing I ever did. But I did it. (twice - the last time was 30 years ago.) If I can do it, anyone can. One day you will wake up and KNOW you can do it that day and you will.

Smoking=Death

Well, it's anti-social, too, but when all of your friends smoke, that's probably not a big concern.
I can name a few: alcoholism, drug addiction,  sexually perversity. Seen through that lens, smoking, as disgusting as it is, pales in comparison.
I can think of a few. Alcoholism, drug addiction, sexual perversity, I could go on. Smoking, as disgusting as it is, does not hold a candle to those sins.
